conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The distance between the two objects at any given time is determined by the difference in their positions, which can be found by calculating the area under each velocity-time graph up to that time.
Object A has a constant velocity, represented by a straight line.
Object B has a velocity that changes over time, represented by a curve.
The position of an object at any time \( t \) is given by the area under its velocity-time graph from \( t = 0 \) to \( t \).
The distance between the two objects at any time \( t \) is the absolute difference between the areas under the two graphs up to that time.

premise: The maximum separation occurs when the difference in the areas under the two graphs is the greatest.
conclusion: From \( t = 0 \) to \( t_1 \), object B is moving slower than object A, so the distance between them increases.

conclusion: At \( t_1 \), object B starts to move faster than object A, so the distance between them starts to decrease.

conclusion: The maximum separation occurs at \( t_1 \), just before object B starts to catch up to object A.
